id: bigtech:waymo to roll out driverless taxis on highways in three us c:2025-11-13T15:30:49.000Z
title: Waymo to roll out driverless taxis on highways in three US cities
author: Rafe Rosner-Uddin, Financial Times
summary_long: Waymo is set to expand its self-driving taxi service onto highways in three US cities on Wednesday, an advance for the venture owned by Google’s parent company that raises the stakes on safety. The company said it would add the high-speed roads to its routes in Los Angeles, Phoenix, and San Francisco, allowing Waymo cars to ferry passengers to more destinations including San Jose International Airport. Waymo’s rollout on highways marks a significant step for the robotaxi operator as it aims to encourage the mass adoption of driverless vehicles. It is the first time a company will carry out paid driverless services on the highway without a driver behind the wheel. Source: arstechnica.com. Date: 2025-11-13. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: space:blue origin launches twin mars probes for nasa as new glenn :2025-11-13T22:39:00.000Z
title: Blue Origin launches twin Mars probes for NASA as New Glenn makes first landing
author: William Harwood
summary_long: Blue Origin launched its second heavy-lift New Glenn rocket Thursday, putting two small NASA satellites onto a long, looping course to Mars to learn more about how the sun has slowly blown away the red planet’s once thick atmosphere. The centerpiece of Amazon- and Blue Origin-founder Jeff Bezos’ space ambitious, the towering 321-foot tall New Glenn rocket’s seven methane-burning main engines ignited at 3:55 p.m. EST, majestically pushing the booster skyward atop 3.8 million pounds of thrust. The launching came four days late due to stormy weather on Earth and in space where a powerful solar storm buffeted the upper atmosphere with a torrent of high-energy radiation that could have caused electrical problems with the rocket or its payloads. Source: spaceflightnow.com. Date: 2025-11-13. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: consumer:apple suffers setback in uk app store fee lawsuit:2025-11-13T20:46:27.000Z
title: Apple suffers setback in UK App Store fee lawsuit
summary_long: Apple will not be granted a preliminary option for appealing a landmark antitrust ruling in the UK. In October, the country's Competition Appeal Tribunal determined that Apple benefited from "near absolute market power" over app distribution and in-app payments and was "abusing its dominant position by charging excessive and unfair prices" as developer commission. At the time, Apple was reportedly planning to appeal, but today, the Tribunal refused to give the company permission to challenge its decision. That means Apple's next recourse, if it wants to not pony up more than £1 billion in damages, is to take its case directly to the UK Court of Appeal. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2025-11-13. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: space:nasa blue origin launch two spacecraft to study mars solar w:2025-11-14T04:03:20.000Z
title: NASA, Blue Origin Launch Two Spacecraft to Study Mars, Solar Wind
author: Jennifer M. Dooren
summary_long: NASA’s ESCAPADE (Escape and Plasma Acceleration and Dynamics Explorers) mission launched at 3:55 p.m. EST atop a Blue Origin New Glenn rocket at Launch Complex 36 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida. Credit: Blue Origin A pair of NASA spacecraft ultimately destined for Mars will study how its magnetic environment is impacted by the Sun. The mission also will help the agency prepare for future human exploration of Mars. Source: www.nasa.gov. Date: 2025-11-14. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: consumer:blue origins new glenn rocket safely made it to space a seco:2025-11-13T23:03:24.000Z
title: Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket safely made it to space a second time
summary_long: Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket has completed its second flight, The Washington Post reports. The rocket launched from Florida's Cape Canaveral Space Force Station on Thursday, and successfully separated from its first-stage booster, which later landed on a sea platform Blue Origin calls "Jacklyn." The launch marks the first time the space startup has been able to catch a New Glenn booster for later reuse. The maiden flight of the rocket in January was successful in the sense that it got New Glenn into space, but Blue Origin wasn't able to save the booster from a watery grave. The company hoped to launch its second New Glenn mission on November 9, but cancelled it last minute due to weather. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2025-11-13. Why it matters: outline likely impact on technology, business, or society. What’s next: note near-term developments or signals to watch.

id: consumer:tesla is reportedly testing apple carplay in its vehicles:2025-11-13T19:25:05.000Z
title: Tesla is reportedly testing Apple CarPlay in its vehicles
author: Andre Revilla
summary_long: Tesla may finally be capitulating to the calls of iPhone users wanting what practically every other major automaker offers them, Apple CarPlay. Bloomberg is reporting that the EV giant is working to add Apple’s car infotainment integration to its vehicles, according to the outlet’s sources. The feature has reportedly begun internal testing and could be ready for release in the coming months. Of course, development and testing of the feature is not a guarantee that it sees the light of day. Source: www.engadget.com. Date: 2025-11-13. id: policy:forthcoming digital omnibus would mark point of no return:2025-11-13T08:01:46.000Z
title: Forthcoming Digital Omnibus would mark point of no return
author: EDRi
summary_long: 127 civil society organisations and unions are urging the European Commission to halt its planned Digital Omnibus, warning that the proposals would weaken core EU laws like the GDPR and AI Act, and represent the biggest rollback of digital rights in EU history. The post Forthcoming Digital Omnibus would mark point of no return appeared first on European Digital Rights (EDRi). Source: edri.org. Date: 2025-11-13.
